Award.AwardTitle: REU/RET Site: Penn State REU and RET in Interdisciplinary Materials Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL PART: It is clear that the traditional disciplinary boundaries between chemistry, physics, and engineering are becoming blurred as modern research requires the expertise of multiple disciplines and collaborative research to be successful. This Research Experience for Undergraduates and Teachers in Interdisciplinary Materials Physics is jointly hosted by the Physics Department and the Center for Nanoscale Science (a DMR Materials Research Science and Engineering Center) at Penn State. It will engage a highly diverse group of 17 undergraduate students and 6 teachers each year in hands-on mentored research within the fields of materials physics and interdisciplinary materials. Students and teachers will learn and apply cutting-edge scientific techniques and experience the challenges and rewards of working in a collaborative, interdisciplinary research environment. They will learn and practice important skills for conveying science and its discoveries through professional development activities that include scientific seminars, professional networking events, and outreach activities. Outside the lab, the Site will expose students to the excitement of interdisciplinary research through facilities tours, research seminars, and networking events. Teachers will gain material science knowledge and transfer their experiences back to their students, influencing them and their communities through the development of teaching resources with their peers and Penn State faculty. Students will be inspired to pursue careers in science and engineering, subsequently increasing representation in science from underrepresented groups, including minorities and women.

TECHNICAL PART: Interdisciplinary Materials Physics is a broad range of research topics spanning from the design, creation, and characterization of novel materials to the theoretical understanding of atomic interactions within materials. Students will participate in a 10 week mentored research experience in condensed matter and materials physics or in interdisciplinary nano-materials conducted in labs within Penn State's Physics Department or the cross-disciplinary cohort of labs participating in the Center for Nanoscale Science. Research topics will span studies in complex materials, thin films, superconductivity, semi-conductors, magnetism, and novel properties of nanoscale structures. To complement their research training, students will engage in professional development focusing on the benefits of interdisciplinary science and on communicating science to both professional and public audiences. The culmination of their research experiences will be to present their work at a cross-disciplinary undergraduate research symposium at Penn State.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2015 to 2018, this NSF-REU Site: Penn State's Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) in Interdisciplinary Materials Physics supported or partially supported 38 students to participate in 10 weeks of individual materials research projects in experimental, theoretical, or computational research in condensed matter physics or novel nanoscale materials.  In line with NSF-REU goals, 69% of these REU students were from undergraduate institutions where research is limited, and 54% were from typically underrepresented minority groups. In 2019, this award partially supported on REU student who otherwise participated in research associated with a different award (DMR 1851987). From 2015-2018 this REU site collaborated with Penn State's Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (NSF-MRSEC), and brought in 39 more students funded by MRSEC, for a total of 77 NSF-funded students to participate in cutting edge individual research projects and career-preparatory professional development activities organized by this REU-Site.  The REU impact was further broadened by inviting 21 Penn State Physics majors  and  2 students from Mexico supported by the Penn State Physics Department to join the program and serve as 'hosts' to the visiting students. This diverse group of students was mentored by top researchers on independent research projects, attended weekly seminars, participated in professional development workshops, and engaged in outreach activities all of which provided them experience in research and professional preparation for the excitement and challenges of graduate school and future STEM careers. 

This site also supported 9 teachers (joined by 14 others by other NSF funding sources -  supplementary grants and the Penn State MRSEC) to engage in a 6-week research experience, where they engaged in their own research projects with faculty and their research labs and participated in workshops in nanotechnology and other scientific issues. Five participated twice to further develop their research projects and/or lesson-plans. In all, 18 different teachers participated in the REU/RET site activities over 3 years, of which 7 were from low-income schools (5 in PA, 3 participated twice), 2 were from minority serving schools. Teachers gained material science knowledge which they transferred to classroom activities through their development of take-home resources in collaboration with their peers, Penn State faculty and their research groups. Teachers who returned for a second year added to the program by contributing content to the workshop activities, by sharing prior RET lesson plans with other teacher participants.

This REU Site emphasized the importance of both the interdisciplinary nature of materials research and scientific communication. 99% of students reported that they gained appreciation of how research in materials is interdisciplinary. Student and teachers were also trained in and practiced presentation skills. They all presented their research outcomes via oral and poster presentations at a multi-site end-of summer research symposium at Penn State each year. 31 publications and 32 national or local conference presentations which were produced with undergraduate and teacher researchers who participated in this program, including all NSF funded students. 65% of graduated NSF funded REU students from 2015-2018 began graduate or professional school in science and engineering another 9% started STEM careers.

This REU and RET site also provided a broader impact to the institutional and local communities. Locally, REU students participated in outreach to the local community by presenting science demos during the Pennsylvania Festival of the Arts Children's Day.  RET fellows brought their research back to their students in the classroom in the form of lesson plans and research share-outs to students and colleagues. Institutionally, graduate and postdoctoral mentors of REU students were impacted through their professional mentor training provided by the REU program and through mentoring practice helping to improve their own skill-set for future careers.
